Situation1: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The weekly study circle meets tonight to discuss a chapter they have not yet reviewed.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as I pulled up to the curb, my shift nearly over. Two travelers waved me down, their arms full of suitcases, faces flushed with exhaustion. “Can you help us load these? We’re splitting the fare to the airport,” one said, hopeful. I nodded, feeling the familiar tug of duty—professional service meant more than just driving; it meant patience, strength, and a welcoming smile, no matter how tired I was. But tonight was the weekly study circle at the temple, and I hadn’t yet read the chapter on compassion and detachment. My teacher always said true understanding came from reflection, not just attendance. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss another session, not after last week’s absence. Yet here I was, hands on the trunk, heart pulled in two directions: serve my passengers well, or honor my commitment to spiritual growth. The weight of their luggage seemed lighter than the burden of this choice.
